awd_titl_txt: NSF INCLUDES DDLP: Indigenous Math Circles Communities
awd_abstract_narration:
This NSF INCLUDES Design and Development Launch Pilot is to expand the Navajo Nation Math Circle model to other sites, and to develop and launch a network of math circles based on the NNMC model. The Navajo Nation Math Circle model is a novel approach to broadening the participation of indigenous peoples in mathematics that, ultimately, seeks to improve American Indian students' attitudes towards mathematics, persistence with challenging problems, and grades in math courses. Navajo Nation Math Circles bring teachers, students, and mathematicians together to work collaboratively on challenging, but meaningful and fun, math problems. Through this NSF INCLUDES project, additional math circles across the Navajo Nation will be launched and a mirror site in Washington State serving additional tribes (such as Puyallup, Muckleshoot, Tulalip, and Stillaguamish) will be established.
 
Originating approximately a century ago in Eastern Europe as a means to engage students in mathematical thinking, math circles bring teachers, students, and math professionals together to work collaboratively on challenging, but relevant and interesting, math problems. Navajo Nation Math Circles, established math circles in various Navajo Nation communities, are the foundation of this INCLUDES project. One goal of this effort is to launch a network with the capacity to support the replication and adaption of math circles in multiple sites as an innovative strategy for encouraging indigenous math engagement through culturally enriched open-ended group math explorations. In addition, the Navajo Nation Math Circle model will be expanded to new math circles in the Navajo Nation, as well as in Washington State to serve additional tribes. Cells in the network will implement key elements of the Navajo Nation Math Circle model, adapting them to their particular contexts. Such elements include facilitation of open-ended group math explorations, incorporating indigenous knowledge systems; a Mathematical Visitor Program sending mathematicians to schools to work with students and their teachers; inclusion of mathematics in public festivals to increase community mathematical awareness; a two-week summer math camp for students; and teacher development opportunities ranging from workshops to immersion experiences to a mentoring program pairing teachers with mathematicians.

por.por_cntn:
Indigenous Math Circles bring rich mathematical activities to students and their teachers living in Indigenous communities. This project has three components for students and three components for their teachers. The components for students include regular mathematics festivals, school visits, and Summer math camps. The components for teachers include professional development workshops, immersion programs, and  a mentoring program.

In a festival large numbers of students can come together to explore a wide collection of mathematical activities. Math visitors go to schools to run math activities that inspire and engage students providing motivation to learn more about math. Summer camps provide a unique experience where students can explore mathematics, along with social, cultural, and physical activities in a supportive, low-stress environment.

Teacher workshops let teachers see math activities from the student point of view and exchange instructional ideas with a group of their peers. Immersions allow small numbers of teachers to explore the math circle model over a longer period. The teacher mentoring program pairs teachers with math educators to plan and run math enrichment activities with their students either during or after school.

The objectives of this project were to expand the Navajo Nation Math Circles project and launch a mirror program in Washington State. Significant progress was made on both objectives prior to the pandemic. Several festivals and professional development workshops were run in Washington State, a regular classroom visitor program was launched at Licton Springs school, and a Summer math camp was run in the Yakama Nation.

There were many mathematical classroom visits in the Navajo Nation, and several teachers participated in the mentoring program. The Navajo Math Circles added a Math Camp in Page, AZ to serve the western agencies. The pandemic did disrupt this project. It hit the Dine' community especially hard, and the community was very cautious locking down and restricting gathering for longer than most of the rest of the country. This caused the program to contract. Thus the objective in the Navajo Nation shifted more to sustaining the existing program as opposed to expanding the program.

The Navajo Nation Math Circles program did survive the pandemic and is now expanding again. It is unlikely that the program would have survived the pandemic without the support of this NSF grant.

The project did demonstrate that it would be possible, but difficult, to run a similar program in Washington State. The festivals and classroom visitor program were especially successful. To run a successful math camp requires enough students who are interested in the camp. The process becomes easier the more times a camp is repeated. The population of the Navajo Nation is around 200,000 which is large enough to include enough students interested in exploring mathematics to spend part of their summer doing so. The population of the Yakama Nation is closer to 20,000. The camp that was run there demonstrated that it would be possible to recruit enough students to run a successful math camp. However, doing so is difficult and the stars have to align for such a program to work before it is fully established. The Washington program did not survive the pandemic. The PIs hope such a program may be relaunched and supported in the future.
